review.title: Arc-swift: A Novel Transition System for Dependency Parsing
review.abstract: Transition-based dependency parsers often need sequences of local shift and reduce operations to produce certain attachments. Correct individual decisions hence require global information about the sentence context and mistakes cause error propagation. This paper proposes a novel transition system, arc-swift, that enables direct attachments between tokens farther apart with a single transition. This allows the parser to leverage lexical information more directly in transition decisions. Hence, arc-swift can achieve significantly better performance with a very small beam size. Our parsers reduce error by 3.7--7.6% relative to those using existing transition systems on the Penn Treebank dependency parsing task and English Universal Dependencies.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Dependency sparsers are a long-standing task of natural language processing, the results of which are crucial for various downstream tasks such as relationship extraction (Schmitz et al., 2012; Angeli et al., 2015), language modeling (Gubbins and Vlachos, 2013), and natural logical conclusions (Bowman et al., 2016). Attractive for their linear time complexity and appropriateness compared to conventional classification methods, transition-based dependency sparsers have lately aroused much research interest. A transit-based parser makes sequential predictions of transitions between states under the constraints of a transition system (Nivre, 2003). Transition-based parsers indicate that they arise when parsing shorter-term dependence structures, as well as languages in which non-projective parses are less common (McDonald and Nivre, 2007), secondary predictions of transitions between states under the constraints of a transition system (Nivre, 2003).

sections.heading: 4.1 Data and Model
sections.text: We use the part of the Wall Street Journal of Penn Treebank with standard parsing splits (PTBSD), together with Universal Dependencies v1.3 (Nivre et al., 2016) (EN-UD). PTB-SD is converted after prior work with CoreNLP 3.3.0 (Manning et al., 2014) into Stanford Dependencies (De Marneffe and Manning, 2008). We report labeled and unlabeled attachment values (LAS / UAS), removing punctuations from all ratings. Our model is similar to that of (Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016), where features from tokens are extracted with bi-directional LSTMs and linked for classification. In the three traditional transition systems, features of the top 3 tokens on the stack and the left-most mark in the buffer are linked as classification input.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: One notable difference, however, is that their transitions retain signs between the head and the dependant. Ferna ́ ndez-Gonza ́ lez and Go ́ mezRodrí guez (2012) extended the arc-eager system to include transitions that work on the buffer, but that shorten the transition sequence by reducing the number of required shift transitions. However, limited by the sparse feature-based classifiers used, both of these parsers only extend direct bindings of distance up to 3 and 2 working on the buffer, respectively, which shorten the transition sequence by reducing the number of required shift transitions.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced arc-swift, a novel transition system for dependency parsing. We also performed linguistic analysis of parser outputs and showed that arc-swift parsers reduce errors associated with adverbial attachments compared to parsers using traditional transition systems.

A notable difference is that their transitions retain tokens between the head and dependent. Fernández-González and GómezRodrı́guez (2012) augmented the arc-eager system with transitions that operate on the buffer, which shorten the transition sequence by reducing the number of Shift transitions needed. However, limited by the sparse feature-based classifiers used, both of these parsers just mentioned only allow direct attachments of distance up to 3 and 2, respectively. More recently, Sartorio et al. (2013) extended arc-standard with transitions that directly attach to left and right “spines” of the top two nodes in the stack.

For a comprehensive study of transition systems for dependency parsing, we refer the reader to (Bohnet et al., 2016), which proposed a generalized framework that could derive all of the traditional transition systems we described by configuring the size of the active token set and the maximum arc length, among other control parameters.
